meta.content: Quantification of Valleys of Randomly Textured Substrates as a Function of Opening Angle: Correlation to the Defect Density in Intrinsic nc-Si:H

Optical and electrical properties of hydrogenated nanocrystalline silicon (nc-Si:H) solar cells are strongly influenced by the morphology of underlying substrates. By texturing the substrates, the photogenerated current of nc-Si:H solar cells can increase due to enhanced light scattering. These textured substrates are, however, often incompatible with defect-less nc-Si:H growth resulting in lower Voc and FF. In this study we investigate the correlation between the substrate morphology, the nc-Si:H solar-cell performance, and the defect density in the intrinsic layer of the solar cells (i-nc-Si:H). Statistical surface parameters representing the substrate morphology do not show a strong correlation with the solar-cell parameters. Thus, we first quantify the line density of potentially defective valleys of randomly textured ZnO substrates where the opening angle is smaller than 130° (ρ<130). This ρ<130 is subsequently compared with the solar-cell performance and the defect density of i-nc-Si:H (ρdefect), which is obtained by fitting external photovoltaic parameters from experimental results and simulations. We confirm that when ρ<130 increases the Voc and FF significantly drops. It is also observed that ρdefect increases following a power law dependence of ρ<130. This result is attributed to more frequently formed defective regions for substrates having higher ρ<130.

div.div:
Hydrogenated nanocrystalline silicon (nc-Si:H) has a higher absorption coefficient for long wavelength light (600–1100 nm) than hydrogenated amorphous silicon alloys (i.e., a-Si:H and a-SiO
x
:H). For this reason, nc-Si:H has been widely used as material for the bottom subcell in multijunction thin-film silicon solar cells.
(1-6)
To obtain highly efficient nc-Si:H solar cells it is essential to enhance the photogenerated current, which is generally achieved by scattering the incoming light efficiently into the intrinsic nc-Si:H layers. This light scattering can be enhanced by manipulating the substrate morphology.
(7-18)
In this way the average optical path-length is increased and, consequently, the photogenerated current of nc-Si:H solar cells increases.

On the other hand, the morphology of the substrates also influences the material properties of nc-Si:H such as the crystalline fraction, the preferential crystal orientation, the growth direction, and the density of defective regions in nc-Si:H, which in turn strongly affect the external photovoltaic parameters of nc-Si:H solar cells.
(19)
Although it is well-known that these material properties depend on the deposition conditions during the nc-Si:H growth (i.e., gas flow ratios, substrate temperature, power density, and deposition pressure), the formation of defective regions in nc-Si:H is to a large extent determined by the substrate morphology. Even when using deposition conditions of state-of-the-art nc-Si:H solar cells, defective regions in nc-Si:H have been observed when fabricated on extremely textured substrates.
(9, 18-23)
During the columnar growth on textured substrates, nc-Si:H columns collide more easily with each other, leading to the formation of defective regions. It was reported that these defective regions of nc-Si:H are formed more likely when the opening angle on the textured substrate (θ
open
) is smaller than certain critical angles (110–135°).
(19, 24-26)
The presence of these defective regions in nc-Si:H substantially reduces the open-circuit voltage (
V
oc
) and fill factor (FF) of solar cells, leading to lower power conversion efficiency.
(19, 23)
Thus, in order to ensure both high quality nc-Si:H growth and light scattering,
gently
textured surfaces that do not generate defective regions but still enable sufficient light scattering are needed. So far, the light scattering capability has been fairly well predicted by the root-mean-square roughness (σ
rms
) and correlation length (
l
c
) of the textured surfaces.
(17, 27-29)
Both the σ
rms
and
l
c
, however, only describe the height distribution of the substrates and the lateral feature size, respectively, in a
statistical
way. Consequently, the real morphology of substrates can be different even when they have the same σ
rms
and
l
c
. Therefore, σ
rms
and
l
c
are not unique properties of randomly textured substrates and cannot fully represent their characteristic morphology. For this reason, their correlation to the defective region formation in nc-Si:H is unclear
(12)
and so is the relation with the electrical performance of nc-Si:H solar cells. For a more distinctive analysis and interpretation on the defective region formation in nc-Si:H, it is additionally necessary to take into account other surface characteristics, such as θ
open
and slope distributions as well as statistical surface parameters (σ
rms
,
l
c
, Kurtosis (
R
ku
) and Skewness (
R
sk
)).
(19, 20)
In this way, a more comprehensive analysis can be established.

In this study, we investigate the correlation between the substrate morphology, the p-i-n nc-Si:H solar-cell performance and subsequently the defect density (ρ
defect
) in the intrinsic layer of the solar cells (i-nc-Si:H). In order to analyze the substrate morphology more precisely in addition to the statistical surface parameters, we first quantify the line density of valleys of randomly textured ZnO substrates having θ
open
smaller than a certain angle, θ (ρ
<θ
). This ρ
<θ
is deduced from the height distribution functions,
z
i,j
(
x
i
,

j
), obtained by the atomic force microscopy (AFM) over the entire measured area. Consequently, ρ
<θ
is neither a statistical nor an average parameter, but practical value containing detailed information on the measured substrates. The ρ
defect
is obtained by fitting external photovoltaic parameters from experimental results to simulation results from the Advanced Semiconductor Analysis (ASA) simulation software.
(16)
In this contribution, we demonstrate a strong correlation between the line density of the valleys where defective regions likely grow in the nc-Si:H, the fabricated nc-Si:H solar-cell performance, and finally the ρ
defect
of the i-nc-Si:H.

div.h2: 3 Solar Cells and Simulations: Correlation between Valleys and Defect Density of i-nc-Si:H

div.div:
In this section, nc-Si:H solar cells fabricated on the ZnO substrates used for characterization are investigated experimentally and compared to simulations. The solar cells from EPFL have the following structure: Front ZnO/p-nc-SiO
x
:H/i-nc-Si:H/n-nc-SiO
x
:H/Back ZnO/Back metal contact. The solar cells from TU Delft have the same structure, except that the back ZnO was omitted. The formation of defective regions in nc-Si:H is also to a large extent influenced by the i-nc-Si:H thickness and deposition conditions as well as the substrate morphology.
(9, 10, 31-34)
To rule out this influence, all solar cells had the same i-layer thickness of around 1.1 μm and were deposited in the same deposition run at each institute. The maximal standard deviation in the measured parameters is 2 mV for the
V
OC
, 0.05 mA/cm
2
for the short-circuit current-density (
J
SC
), 0.01 for the FF, and 0.07% for the efficiency (η). Detailed information on the deposition conditions of these solar cells can be found elsewhere.
(18, 19)
In
Figure 4
, the photovoltaic parameters of nc-Si:H solar cells are shown as a function of the average ρ
<130
.

div.p:
Figure 4. Photovoltaic parameters of nc-Si:H solar cells fabricated on different ZnO layers having various ρ
<130
.

div.div:
When the average ρ
<130
is close to zero, high
V
oc
of ∼0.55 V and FF of ∼0.7 with a reasonably high
J
sc
of ∼22 mA/cm
2
is found for the nc-Si:H solar cells. As a result, their efficiencies are around 9%. This implies that the deposition conditions of these prepared nc-Si:H solar cells are fairly decent and that the cells do not contain many defective regions due to underlying substrates. As ρ
<130
increases, it is observed that the
V
oc
and FF continuously decrease. For the solar cell fabricated on B1, which has the highest ρ
<130
of all A- and B-type samples,
V
oc
and FF are also the lowest and, as a result, the efficiency ends up at less than 4%. Since all nc-Si:H solar cells are fabricated in the same deposition run at each institute, this deterioration is attributed to the significant formation of defective regions in the cell and not to their deposition conditions. The
J
sc
of the nc-Si:H solar cells from EPFL tends to increase as ρ
<130
increases, because light scattering is enhanced. On the contrary, it is observed that the
J
sc
of nc-Si:H solar cells from TU Delft continuously decreases with increasing ρ
<130
. This drop in
J
sc
can be mainly ascribed to the higher
k
value of the ZnO:Al fabricated at lower
T
h
leading to significant parasitic absorption.

The performance of these two different types of solar cells fabricated on ZnO:B and ZnO:Al is also influenced by other factors in addition to the substrate morphology. These factors mainly include the sheet resistance and optical properties of transparent conductive oxides (TCOs), shunt and series resistance of the solar cells, and the crystalline fraction of the i-nc-Si:H absorber layer. Therefore, comparing potentially defective regions between these solar cells directly from photovoltaic parameters only may not be sufficient. For this reason we make a correlation between the substrate morphology and ρ
defect
of the intrinsic layer in nc-Si:H solar cells. Therefore, we carried out optical and electrical simulations of the nc-Si:H solar cells using the ASA simulation software and obtained ρ
defect
. These simulations were performed with the input parameters obtained from measurements: the wavelength-dependent complex refractive index of all layers; the thickness of each layer; the height distribution function of the front TCOs, n-layers, and back TCOs; the activation energy of the p- and n-doped layers; the dark current activation energy of the solar cell (and thereby the mobility gap); the crystalline fraction of nc-Si:H layers in a p–i–n device (thereby rescaled densities of states at the conduction and valence band edges); series and shunt resistances. Detailed procedures and discussions on these simulations can be found elsewhere.
(23)
During simulations only the ρ
defect
of the i-nc-Si:H layers of solar cells was varied to fit experimental results to simulation results: external photovoltaic parameters, dark- and photo
I
–
V
curves, dark current activation energy of solar cells, and external quantum efficiency. The applicability of 1D simulations for thin-film silicon solar cells on randomly textured substrates has been widely reported and accepted by many researchers.
(35-45)
These simulation results have been shown to fit and correlate well to measurement results and, therefore, the defect density obtained from matching these simulations to measurements reflects well the properties of the materials making up the device.

In
Figure 5
ρ
defect
of i-nc-Si:H layers of solar cells are presented as a function of ρ
<130

values are in the range of 4–6 × 10
15
cm
–3
when ρ

<130

<130

<130
is 1438 cm
–1
(B1), which is the highest ρ

Figure 4

defect
of i-nc-Si:H has the highest value of 3.5 × 10
16
cm

. Note again that the 1.1-μm thick i-nc-Si:H from each EPFL and Delft were fabricated in the same deposition run at each institute and the nc-Si:H solar cell with the i-nc-Si:H layers on relatively flat substrates showed reasonably good PV parameters. Therefore, we think that the strong correlation between ρ
defect
of nc-Si:H and ρ
<130
found in this study should be attributed to the significant formation of defective regions due to the underlying substrate. Planar converters contg. quantum dots as wavelength-shifting moieties on top of a multicryst. silicon and an amorphous silicon solar cell were studied. The highly efficient quantum dots are to shift the wavelengths where the spectral response of the solar cell is low to wavelengths where the spectral response is high, in order to improve the conversion efficiency of the solar cell. It was calcd. that quantum dots with an emission at 603 nm increase the multicryst. solar cell short-circuit current by nearly 10%. Simulation results for planar converters on hydrogenated amorphous silicon solar cells show no beneficial effects, due to the high spectral response at low wavelength.

The anal. of microelectronic and photonic structures (AMPS) transport-simulation computer program was used to show that a distinction can be made between the effects of light-induced bulk and interfacial degrdn. in hydrogenated amorphous Si (α-Si:H) p-i-n detector and solar cell structures. Using reverse bias leakage (dark) currents, AMPS simulations show that, for p and n layers that do not allow significant injection of electrons and holes into the intrinsic layer of the p-i-n structure, a light-induced increase in the d. of interfacial states will result in significantly different changes in the voltage behavior of the reverse bias dark currents than will a corresponding increase in the d. of bulk defect states. A careful study of the reverse bias dark currents can provide an excellent means of detg. if light soaking of a-Si:H p-i-n devices results in bulk degrdn., interfacial degrdn., or both.
